newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU bans sale of BSE-risk cosmetics.
newsitem.headline: EU bans sale of BSE-risk cosmetics.

text.p: The European Commission, in a move to combat the dangers of mad cow disease, said on Monday it had formally banned the marketing of cosmetic products containing ingredients derived from cattle, sheep and goats.
"The ban translates into legal terms a situation that already exists in the cosmetics industry," the Commission said in a statement.
Britain announced last March that the fatal brain disease properly known as Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy (BSE) could be be transmitted to humans in the form of Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD).
The Commission said the ban was a precautionary measure to ensure consumer safety without waiting for irrefutable proof of a link between BSE and CJD.
A Commission spokesman said the cosmetics industry had for the past five years banned the use of brain, spinal cord and eye tissue from cattle, sheep and goats.
The EU ban, which follows France's call for safeguard measures last September, must be transposed into national legislation by July 1997.
Rory Macmillan, communications and information manager for the European Cosmetic, Toiletry and Perfumery Association, said the move transposed existing practice into legal reality.
"From the point of view of industry, it does not have an impact because we are already doing it," he told Reuters.
